body:
First, you need to try it on PowerShell Core, as this is only for PowerShell Core issues.  So, for Windows PowerShell issues, use Uservoice at: https://windowsserver.uservoice.com/forums/301869-powershell 

Overall, this type of exception can only be handle using the try/catch.  

In order to reproduce in PowerShell Core, we need better steps. We don't know what commands are executing in "Cradle.ps1" script file.

Keep in mind, Microsoft efforts are to move forward with PowerShell Core.

:)

You cannot tell what is in a text file?  I am very confused.  Have you tried notepad?  

To help I have opened the files in notepad and copied the text files here.

```
#cradle.ps1

# Set the error action to Stop
$ErrorActionPreferenceOld = $ErrorActionPreference
$ErrorActionPreference = "Stop"

. .\error.ps1

try {
     Write-Host "Running"
     DoIt
} catch {
    Write-Host "There was an error"
    Format-list * -InputObject $_ -Force
} finally {
     Write-Host "Finished"
     $ErrorActionPreference = $ErrorActionPreferenceOld
}
```

```
#error.ps1

function DoIt {
    [CmdletBinding]
    Write-Host "Before"
    # Perform action which prints to error stream
    Invoke-Command -Script {
        & cmd.exe /k "echo 'test' 1&>2" *>1 | Out-Null
    } -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue | Out-Null -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
    Write-Host "After"
}
```

Just in case you are confused you will need to copy AND paste these into the following files and please read the first line of the code as those correspond to the files that you need to copy and paste into,

```
cradle.ps1
error.ps1
```

then at the command line please type,

```
.\cradle.ps1
```

Please let me know if that was not clear.  


I have also tried in a try catch and it still throws in my real script and not this toy example and it still fails.

I reproduced it in PowerShell Core, here is the version I have.  I will also file a bug with the PowerShell team.

```
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      6.1.0-preview.4
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    6.1.0-preview.4
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.17134
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

Here's a reduced version of the code with just the relevant bits.
```powershell
$ErrorActionPreference="silentlycontinue"
Invoke-Command -Script {
        & cmd.exe /c 1 *>1 | Out-Null
} -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
```
This will indeed generate a error despite setting `-ErrorAction` on `Invoke-Command`. This is because `$ErrorActionPreference` is set to `Stop`. The preference variable is the ambient setting for all commands vs. the `-ErrorAction` parameter that controls the behaviour for a specific command. This means that when cmd.exe is executed, it's error action will be `Stop` causing an exception to be thrown. As @MaximoTrinidad points out, you could capture that exception with `try/catch`. On the other hand, you could change the setting of `$ErrorActionPreference` to be something other than `Stop`. You could even set it inside the `Invoke-Command` scriptblock so it's local to that block:
```powershell
$ErrorActionPreference="stop"
Invoke-Command -Script {
	$ErrorActionPreference="silentlycontinue"
        & cmd.exe /c 1 *>1 | Out-Null
} -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
```
Ultimately there is no PowerShell bug here - everything is working as intended - however I'd encourage you to look at your overall error handling approach since you appear to have conflicting preferences.

Ah! Apologoies @deathly809 !!  

I didn't notice you included other files.  Hehe!!

Thanks BruceP for assisting!!
Hmmm, I will override the setting and see what happens.  Hopefully that fixes it.  Thanks!

Hey guys, this does not seem to be fixed. Is this by design? Invoke-Command does not respect -ErrorAction parameter which means it cannot be suppressed using SilentlyContinue nor can it be trapped using aTry..Catch block.

This issue is present in both WinPS and PowerShell Core. Does not seem like intended behavior since the $Error[0] variable and $ResolutionError ErrorVariable are set by PowerShell outside of the scriptblock.

`Invoke-Command -ScriptBlock { Get-Content c:\file\does\not\exist.txt } -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue -ErrorVariable ResolutionError`

For anyone else still seeing this, ErrorAction on Invoke-Command doesn't affect the error action inside the block you pass to Invoke-Command, just the error action for Invoke-Command and its logic. If you're passing a ScriptBlock into a function in another context, $ErrorActionPrefence inside the script block will not be affected by $ErrorActionPreference in the function that invokes the script block. $ErrorActionPreference appears to behave like any other scoped variable, so changing it in the calling function doesn't affect the value captured by the script block. ### With ExecuteBlock defined in the script ``` powershell function ExecuteBlock([ScriptBlock]$ScriptBlock) { Write-Host " ExecuteBlock start: $ErrorActionPreference" $ErrorActionPreference = "Continue" Write-Host " ExecuteBlock set: $ErrorActionPreference" Invoke-Command -ScriptBlock $ScriptBlock Write-Host " ExecuteBlock end: $ErrorActionPreference" } Write-Host "Script start: $ErrorActionPreference" ExecuteBlock { Write-Host " ScriptBlock: $ErrorActionPreference" } Write-Host "Script end: $ErrorActionPreference" ``` ``` Script start: Stop ExecuteBlock start: Stop ExecuteBlock set: Continue ScriptBlock: Continue ExecuteBlock end: Continue Script end: Stop ``` ### With ExecuteBlock defined in a module. ``` powershell function ExecuteBlock([ScriptBlock]$ScriptBlock) { Write-Host " ExecuteBlock start: $ErrorActionPreference" $ErrorActionPreference = "Continue" Write-Host " ExecuteBlock set: $ErrorActionPreference" Invoke-Command -ScriptBlock $ScriptBlock Write-Host " ExecuteBlock end: $ErrorActionPreference" } Export-ModuleMember -Alias * -Function * ``` ``` powershell Import-Module .\helpers.psm1 -Force Write-Host "Script start: $ErrorActionPreference" ExecuteBlock { Write-Host " ScriptBlock: $ErrorActionPreference" } Write-Host "Script end: $ErrorActionPreference" ``` ``` Script start: Stop ExecuteBlock start: Stop ExecuteBlock set: Continue ScriptBlock: Stop ExecuteBlock end: Continue Script end: Stop ``` The module example proves that setting $ErrorActionPreference before calling Invoke-Command will only affect the ErrorActionPreference in the script block if the script block and the invocation are in the same scope. ### Using InvokeWithContext To invoke a script block from another scope while altering its ErrorActionPreference, you can call InvokeWithContext on the ScriptBlock ``` powershell function ExecuteBlock([ScriptBlock]$ScriptBlock) { Write-Host " ExecuteBlock start: $ErrorActionPreference" $ScriptBlock.InvokeWithContext($null, @([PSVariable]::new('ErrorActionPreference', 'Continue'))) Write-Host " ExecuteBlock end: $ErrorActionPreference" } ``` ``` Script start: Stop ExecuteBlock start: Stop ScriptBlock: Continue ExecuteBlock end: Stop Script end: Stop ``` ## Summing Up ``` powershell function ExecuteBlock([ScriptBlock]$ScriptBlock) { $ScriptBlock.InvokeWithContext($null, @([PSVariable]::new('ErrorActionPreference', 'Continue'))) Write-Host "ExecuteBlock `$? = $?" Write-Host "ExecuteBlock `$LASTEXITCODE = $LASTEXITCODE" } Export-ModuleMember -Alias * -Function * ``` ``` powershell Import-Module .\helpers.psm1 -Force ExecuteBlock { & cmd.exe /c "1" *>&1 } Write-Host "Script `$?: $?" ``` ``` '1' is not recognized as an internal or external command, operable program or batch file. ExecuteBlock $? = True ExecuteBlock $LASTEXITCODE = 1 Script $?: True ``` There is a downside to InvokeWithContext. While it lets you fix up the script blocks closure with variable and function replacements, the $? (completion success) variable appears to apply to InvokeWithContext's processing of the script block, not the success of the last command in the script block. https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/dotnet/api/system.management.automation.scriptblock.invokewithcontext?view=powershellsdk-7.0.0
ScriptBlock.InvokeWithContext Method (System.Management.Automation)
A method that allows a scriptblock to be invoked with additional context in the form of a set of local functions and variables to be defined in the scriptblock's scope. The list of variables may include the special variables $input, $_ and $this.
